definitions: wonderful, excellent, or marvelous in quality or appearance
existing only in imagination; strange, bizarre, or highly imaginative
remarkably large or extreme to the point of seeming unbelievable
examples: The restaurant serves fantastic food at reasonable prices
She did a fantastic job organizing the conference
Dragons and unicorns are fantastic creatures from mythology
The artist created fantastic landscapes that defied reality
The company made fantastic profits during the boom years
He told fantastic tales about his supposed adventures

definitions: existing only in fantasy; wildly fanciful or imaginative in design
remarkably strange or unusual to the point of seeming unreal
examples: The novel describes fantastical worlds beyond human imagination
Children love fantastical stories about magical kingdoms
The palace had fantastical architecture unlike anything else
She wore a fantastical costume covered in feathers

definitions: located at a great distance in space or time
appearing lost in thought or daydreaming; mentally absent
examples: They traveled to faraway lands across the ocean
The faraway mountains looked blue in the distance
She had a faraway look in her eyes
His faraway expression suggested deep contemplation

definitions: resembling a farce; ludicrously absurd or improbable in nature
examples: The trial became farcical when witnesses contradicted themselves
The whole situation was utterly farcical and embarrassing
Their farcical attempts at diplomacy only worsened relations
The meeting descended into farcical chaos

definitions: relating to or engaged in the business of cultivating land and raising crops
examples: The farming community struggled during the drought
Modern farming techniques have increased crop yields
They inherited farming equipment from their grandparents
Sustainable farming practices protect the environment

definitions: at or to a greater distance in space compared to another point
going beyond what exists or has been dealt with; additional
examples: The farther shore of the lake was barely visible
We need to walk farther to reach the summit
Farther investigation revealed new evidence in the case
The farther implications of this decision remain unclear

definitions: at or to the greatest distance in space or time from a reference point
examples: Neptune is the farthest planet from the sun
The farthest corner of the room was dark
They traveled to the farthest reaches of the empire
This is the farthest we've ever been from home

definitions: extremely interested in or attracted to something or someone with intense curiosity
examples: The children were fascinated by the magician's tricks
She seemed fascinated with ancient Egyptian culture
He was utterly fascinated by her stories of travel
Scientists remain fascinated by this mysterious phenomenon

definitions: capable of arousing and holding attention through being extremely interesting or charming
examples: The documentary presented fascinating insights into animal behavior
She tells the most fascinating stories about her travels
It's fascinating to watch skilled craftsmen at work
The museum has a fascinating collection of artifacts

definitions: relating to or characteristic of fascism as a political ideology or system
showing extreme intolerance or authoritarianism in attitudes or behavior
examples: The fascist regime suppressed all political opposition
Fascist governments controlled every aspect of citizens' lives
His fascist attitudes about art stifled creativity
She criticized the company's fascist management style

definitions: conforming to or following current trends in style, especially in clothing
popular or favored at a particular time among influential people
examples: She always wears the most fashionable clothes
That restaurant is very fashionable among celebrities
It became fashionable to criticize traditional values
Sustainable living is increasingly fashionable these days

definitions: made, shaped, or formed in a particular way or style
examples: The sword was fashioned from the finest steel
They fashioned tools from stones and wood
An old-fashioned dress hung in the closet
The newly fashioned agreement satisfied both parties

definitions: fixed, attached, or closed securely in place with a device or tie
examples: Make sure your seatbelt is properly fastened
The gate remained fastened despite the strong wind
All windows should be fastened before the storm
Her coat was fastened with large brass buttons

definitions: showing great attention to detail and accuracy; very careful and precise
having high and often excessive standards; hard to please or satisfy
examples: She kept fastidious records of every transaction
The scientist was fastidious in documenting her experiments
He's fastidious about his appearance and grooming
The fastidious customer complained about every minor flaw

definitions: having too much flesh or adipose tissue; heavier than normal weight
having a large distance between opposite sides; broad or thick
containing or yielding much of something; substantial or profitable
examples: The fat cat could barely fit through the door
He worried about getting fat from eating junk food
She wrote with a fat marker pen
The book had fat pages that made it heavy
They earned fat profits from the investment
He received a fat bonus at year's end

definitions: causing or capable of causing death; mortal or deadly in effect
causing ruin or destruction; having disastrous or decisive consequences
examples: The accident resulted in fatal injuries
The disease can be fatal if left untreated
It was a fatal mistake to trust him
The general made a fatal error in strategy

definitions: predetermined by fate or destiny; certain to happen as if by supernatural force
examples: They seemed fated to meet again after years
The expedition was fated to end in disaster
Their fated encounter changed both their lives forever
He felt fated to follow in his father's footsteps

definitions: having momentous significance or consequences; critically decisive for the future
controlled by fate; ominous or prophetic of disaster
examples: It was a fateful decision to declare war
That fateful day changed the course of history
The oracle spoke fateful words of doom
Dark clouds gathered on that fateful morning

definitions: having no father because of death, absence, or abandonment
examples: The charity supports fatherless children in the community
She grew up fatherless after her dad died
Many fatherless families struggle with financial hardship
The war left thousands of children fatherless

definitions: showing the affectionate care and protective concern typical of a father
examples: He gave her fatherly advice about her career
The coach showed fatherly concern for his players
His fatherly presence comforted the frightened children
She appreciated his fatherly guidance through difficulties

definitions: suffering from extreme physical or mental tiredness; exhausted or weary
examples: The fatigued soldiers could barely stay awake
She felt mentally fatigued after the long exam
Athletes often become fatigued during intense training
The fatigued workers demanded shorter shifts

definitions: containing a large amount of fat or oil; greasy or oily in nature
having the characteristics or appearance of fat tissue; adipose
examples: Fatty foods can raise your cholesterol levels
The doctor warned against eating fatty meats
The biopsy revealed fatty tissue around the organ
Fatty deposits had accumulated in the arteries

definitions: having no defects, mistakes, or weaknesses; perfect in execution or quality
examples: Her faultless performance earned a standing ovation
The diamond had faultless clarity and brilliance
His faultless manners impressed everyone at dinner
The mechanism worked with faultless precision

definitions: having faults, flaws, or defects; not working properly or reliably
containing mistakes or based on incorrect reasoning or information
examples: The faulty wiring caused the fire
They recalled all products with faulty components
His faulty logic led to wrong conclusions
The report was based on faulty assumptions

definitions: made in imitation; artificial or fake but meant to look genuine
examples: She wore a faux fur coat to the party
The walls had faux marble finishing
His faux concern didn't fool anyone
The restaurant had faux French cuisine

definitions: providing an advantage or beneficial conditions; conducive to success
showing or expressing approval, support, or a positive opinion
examples: The favorable weather conditions helped the harvest
They negotiated favorable terms for the contract
The movie received favorable reviews from critics
She made a favorable impression at the interview

definitions: regarded or treated with special preference or partiality
having natural advantages or privileged status
examples: She was the favored candidate for promotion
Their favored restaurant was always crowded
The favored team had home field advantage
Children from favored backgrounds attended elite schools

definitions: preferred above all others of the same kind; most liked or enjoyed
examples: Chocolate is my favorite flavor of ice cream
This is her favorite dress for special occasions
He's the teacher's favorite student
What's your favorite movie of all time?

definitions: providing an advantage or beneficial conditions; conducive to success
showing or expressing approval, support, or a positive opinion
examples: The favourable exchange rate benefited tourists
We're waiting for more favourable conditions
The committee gave a favourable verdict
Initial reactions have been very favourable

definitions: preferred above all others of the same kind; most liked or enjoyed
examples: Tea is the nation's favourite beverage
This park is my favourite place to relax
She's everyone's favourite colleague at work
What's your favourite book?

definitions: feeling or showing fear or anxiety; frightened or apprehensive
causing fear or dread; terrible or frightening in nature
examples: The fearful child hid behind her mother
He was fearful of making another mistake
The storm made fearful noises all night
They faced fearful odds in the battle

definitions: showing no fear in the face of danger or difficulty; brave and bold
examples: The fearless explorer ventured into unknown territory
She was fearless in defending her principles
Fearless journalists exposed corruption despite threats
The fearless warrior led the charge into battle

definitions: causing fear or respect through being impressively powerful, large, or capable
examples: The dragon was a fearsome creature with razor teeth
Their fearsome reputation preceded them everywhere
She had developed fearsome skills in martial arts
The team faced fearsome competition in finals

definitions: possible to do easily or conveniently; capable of being accomplished successfully
examples: The plan seems feasible with our current resources
Is it feasible to complete this by Friday?
They explored feasible alternatives to the proposal
The only feasible solution required more funding

definitions: covered with or having feathers; adorned with feather-like structures
examples: The feathered dinosaur fossil amazed scientists
She wore a feathered headdress to the carnival
All feathered creatures can regulate body temperature
The arrow had feathered fletching for stability

definitions: light, soft, and delicate like feathers in appearance or texture
examples: The plant had feathery fronds that swayed gently
She applied makeup with feathery brush strokes
Feathery clouds drifted across the morning sky
The pastry had light, feathery layers

definitions: given special prominence or attention; highlighted or showcased
having distinctive facial features or characteristics as specified
examples: The featured artist performed three songs
Today's featured special is grilled salmon
The fine-featured model had classical beauty
His sharp-featured face showed determination

definitions: without distinctive or interesting features, qualities, or characteristics; bland
examples: The featureless landscape stretched endlessly
They drove through miles of featureless suburbs
His featureless face was hard to remember
The building had a featureless concrete facade

definitions: relating to or consisting of feces; pertaining to bodily waste matter
examples: The water tested positive for fecal contamination
Fecal samples were collected for laboratory analysis
The doctor ordered a fecal occult blood test
Fecal matter must be properly disposed of

definitions: relating to the central government of a federation rather than state governments
examples: Federal laws override state regulations
She works for a federal agency in Washington
The federal budget increased military spending
Federal investigators took over the case

definitions: joined together in a federal union or alliance of states or organizations
examples: The federated states formed a stronger union
Several companies created a federated network
The federated system allowed local autonomy
Federated databases share information seamlessly

definitions: lacking physical strength, especially as a result of age or illness
lacking force, effectiveness, or conviction; inadequate or unconvincing
examples: His feeble voice could barely be heard
The elderly man's feeble grip worried the doctor
She made a feeble attempt to smile
His feeble excuse didn't convince anyone

definitions: simulated or pretended; not genuine but made to appear so
examples: Her feigned surprise didn't fool anyone
He showed feigned interest in her stories
The actor's feigned emotions seemed very real
She spoke with feigned confidence during presentation

definitions: showing courage, determination, and spirited aggressiveness despite size or position
examples: The feisty little dog barked at larger dogs
She was a feisty competitor who never gave up
The feisty grandmother stood up to the bullies
His feisty personality made him a great debater

definitions: of, relating to, or characteristic of cats or the cat family
resembling a cat in grace, agility, or stealthiness
examples: The zoo's feline exhibit includes lions and tigers
Feline diseases can spread quickly among cats
She moved with feline grace across the stage
His feline reflexes saved him from falling

definitions: fierce, cruel, or terrible in manner or appearance; savage and ruthless
examples: The fell beast terrorized the countryside
They fled from the dragon's fell gaze
With one fell swoop, he destroyed their plans
The tyrant ruled with fell determination

definitions: of or denoting the sex that can bear offspring or produce eggs
examples: Female mammals nurse their young
The female lion does most of the hunting
Female students outnumber males at this university
She was the first female president

definitions: having qualities or characteristics traditionally associated with women
denoting a gender of nouns and adjectives in certain languages
examples: She preferred feminine clothing with lace and ruffles
His feminine sensitivity made him a good counselor
In French, 'table' is a feminine noun
The feminine ending changes the word's meaning

definitions: advocating for women's rights and equality between the sexes
examples: She joined the feminist movement in college
The feminist perspective challenged traditional roles
Feminist scholars researched gender inequality
He proudly identified as a feminist ally

definitions: existing in a wild state, especially after escape from captivity or domestication
examples: Feral cats roamed the abandoned buildings
The island's feral pigs destroyed native plants
He had an almost feral look in his eyes
The children had gone feral during summer vacation
